titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Special Collections Staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-10-26T14:57-0400

did.unittitle: Magnus Jan Krynski Collection
did.abstract: This collection consists of materials that belonged to Magnus Jan Krynski (MJK) of North Carolina. A successful translator, author, educator, and proponent of human rights, Krynski was active in Polish affairs and Polish American politics and culture. A native of Poland, he came to the United States in 1949 and obtained an extensive education which he applied to translate several volumes of Polish poetry into English and also become chairman of Duke University’s Department of Slavic Languages and Literature. There are a plethora of documents relating to his professional life, translating work, and political activity in this collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Magnus Jan (John) Krynski (MJK) (1922-1989) was born in Warsaw, Poland and came to the United States in 1949. He received a Bachelor of Arts from the University of Cincinnati, a Masters of Arts from Brown University, and a PhD in Polish and Russian literature from Columbia University. He was an educator at the University of Pittsburgh, Kenyon College, Ohio State University and Duke University, where he also became a chairman of the Department of Slavic Languages and Literature in 1966. He was an author of many articles about Polish 20th century literature and translator of Polish poetry. Krynski together with Robert A. Maguire were co-translators of three major collections of Polish poetry by Tadeusz Rozewicz, Wisława Szymborska and Anna Swirszczynska. Wislawa Szymborska received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1996. Krynski was an active member of American PEN Club and the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences. In the eighties, he became active in national and local politics. He was active in groups such as Pomost North Carolina, Freedom Foundation, International Society for Human Rights, and the Heritage Foundation. He was a Washington D.C. representative and a founder of American Polish Political Action Committee - AMPOLPAC , chairman of the North Carolina Ethnic Voters for Reagan-Bush and delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1984, and co-founder of the North Carolina Committee for Solidarity with Solidarity. He authored statements, position papers, and memoranda on East-West trade issues, human rights, and economic sanctions for US State Department of National Security Council, and the US Congress. He married Elizabeth Girardet from New Hampshire in 1952 and retired in 1987. He passed away from a heart attack in 1989 in his town of residence Durham, North Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection contains of materials related to Krynski’s work as a scholar, author and educator including manuscripts, printed copies of his articles, drafts of translations, conference papers, research notes, notes from trips to Poland, outgoing/incoming correspondence with Polish writers, scholars, and editors (both in Poland and in the US). Furthermore, it includes memos, letters, and notes related to Duke University’s Slavic Department and documents of Krynski’s political activities such as correspondence, memos, fliers, position papers, news clippings, interviews, and speeches. Also included is a set of transcripts from Jozef Wittlin's Radio Free Europe literary program broadcasted between 1955 and 1966 from New York.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Magnus Jan Krynski Collection (CPAA 91-17). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Mrs. Elizabeth Krynski donated the material to the Connecticut Polish American Archives in 1991, two years after Mr. Krynski's death.
